tip: Use Ctrl+R to search your command history interactively.
Use 'history | grep keyword' to find specific commands in your history.
Chain commands with '&&' to execute the second command only if the first one succeeds.
Chain commands with '||' to execute the second command only if the first one fails.
Use '!' followed by the beginning of a command to execute the most recent command starting with that string (e.g., '!ls').
Use '!!' to refer to the previous command.
Use aliases to create shortcuts for frequently used commands.
Use 'Ctrl+C' to stop a running command.
Use 'Ctrl+Z' to pause a running command and send it to the background.
Use 'fg' to bring a background process to the foreground.
Use 'bg' to send a paused process to the background.
Use the 'man' command to access the manual pages for commands.
Use 'apropos keyword' to search for commands related to a keyword.
Use 'whatis command' for a very brief description of a command.
Use tab completion to quickly complete commands and filenames.
Use 'Ctrl+D' to signal the end of input (EOF) to a program or to exit the current shell.
Use 'clear' or 'Ctrl+L' to clear the terminal screen.
